bibl.title: Minutes of the Annual Meeting, Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 23, 1949

div1.p: The minutes include a treasurer's report, a resolution to transfer a monthly allowance to Blossom Reed upon the death of her mother, a continuation of the $50 increase to Emilie L. Reed, discussion of a plaque to commemorate the location of Reed's death, and comments on the protection of Building No. 1.

div1.head: Minutes of the Annual Meeting, Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 23, 1949
div1.p:
MINUTES
ANNUAL MEETING, BOARD OF MANAGERS, WALTER REED MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION
Washington, D. C., November 23, 1949

The Board met at 10 A.M. in the Board Room, American Security & Trust Company,
15th Street & Pennsylvania Avenue, Northwest, and was called to order by its
President, Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean, U. S. Army, Retired.

PRESENT: Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean, President; Brig. Gen. Frank R. Keefer; Brig. Gen.
Albert G. Love; Lt. Col. W. G. Brandstadt, M.C., U.S.A., representing Major Gen.
R. W. Bliss, Surgeon General, U. S. Army; Dr. Fred L. Soper, Director Pan American
Sanitary Bureau; Hans W. Ireland, Treasurer; Col. J. F. Siler, Med. Corps, U.S.A.,
Retired, Secretary.

ABSENT: Major Gen. M. W. Ireland, Major Gen. C. R. Reynolds, Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor,
Dr. Philip S. Hench and Dr. L. O. Howard.

In view of the fact that copies of the minutes of the last annual meeting (1948)
had been mailed all members of the Board, the reading of the minutes of the last
meeting was omitted and the minutes were approved as written.

The Treasurer submitted the following report, summarizing comparative income
and disbursements for the fiscal years ending Oct. 31, 1948 and Oct. 31, 1949 and
the par and market values of capital investments for like periods of time.

div1.p: The report of the Treasurer was approved.

The following officers were elected for the forthcoming year.
President Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
Vice President Major Gen. Merritte W. Ireland
Treasurer Mr. Hans W. Ireland
Secretary Col. Joseph F. Siler

The President then asked if there was any new business to be given consideration
by the Board.

Col. Siler stated that under date of Sept. 29, 1949, Dr. Hench had written him
that it probably would be impossible for him to attend the annual meeting this year
and he desired to make some suggestions for consideration by the Board at its annual
meeting. Dr. Hench enclosed copies of this letter and one copy was mailed to each
member of the Board for his consideration prior to the annual meeting.

Col. Siler stated that he had discussed with Gen. Kean the matters brought up
by Dr. Hench in his letter of Sept. 29, 1949 and had replied to Dr. Hench's letter
on Oct. 13, 1949. In a subsequent note (Oct. 20, 1949) Dr. Hench advised him that
he would be unable to attend the annual meeting.
The three letters referred to are attached to these minutes as Exhibits A, B & C.

Col. Siler then stated that he desired to present to the Board the matters taken
up by Dr. Hench in his letter of Sept. 29 for such definitive action as may be con-
sidered feasible in the premises. He stated that the first matter referred to by Dr.
Hench was whether the Board could and would authorize the payment of the regular
monthly allowance from the income from the trust fund, to Mrs. Walter Reed's daughter,
Emily (Blossom) Reed, after the death of her mother. Col. Siler called attention to
the fact that Article 1 of the Certificate of Incorporation of the Association reads
as follows:

“FIRST. The name of the association shall be “The Walter Reed Memorial Associa-
tion” and the objects for which it is formed are to commemorate by a suitable memorial
the eminent scientific and public services of the late Major Walter Reed, Surgeon,
U. S. Army, and to raise funds for that object; also to assist, if necessary, with
the income of such fund the wife and daughter of said Walter Reed.”

To cover the matter of payment of the allowance eventually to Blossom Reed, the
following resolution was adopted:

RESOLVED, That on the death of Mrs. Walter Reed the regular monthly allowance
paid to her since October, 1906, from the income received from the trust funds be
paid to her daughter, Emily (Blossom) Reed, until her death, in accordance with the
provisions of the Articles of Incorporation.

Col. Siler stated that the members of the Board would recall that at the annual
meeting last year a resolution was adopted authorizing the Treasurer of the Board
to increase the monthly payment to Mrs. Reed $50.00 per month. This increase be-
came necessary by reason of the fact that Mrs. Reed had been bedridden for more than
two years and required constant nursing care. Her physical condition is essentially
the same as was the case last year except that she continues to lose ground
physically and continuation of the additional $50.00 monthly payments is urgently
required.
To cover these extra payments the following resolution was adopted:

WHEREAS, the BOARD OF MANAGERS OF THE WALTER REED MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION
at their annual meeting held on November 15, 1948, passed a resolution authorizing
the Treasurer of the Association to increase the monthly payment to Mrs. Emily L.
Reed, -- $50.00 (Fifty Dollars) per month beginning November 1, 1948 and continuing
for not more than twelve months.

RESOLVED: THAT the Treasurer of the Association be, and he hereby is,
authorized to continue the increase of $50.00 (Fifty Dollars) per month to Mrs.
Emily L. Reed, for another 12 (Twelve) months beginning November 1, 1949, and
further, should the income of the Association not be sufficient to make this pay-
ment, the Treasurer be, and he is hereby, authorized to sell sufficient of the
capital assets to make such payments.

The second matter given consideration by Dr. Hench was that of placing a modest
wooden sign or bronze plaque on the old hospital building at Ft. Leslie J. McNair,
in which Major Walter Reed was a patient at the time of his death. Col. Siler re-
ported that recently he and Maj. Gen. Walter L. Reed had visited Ft. McNair for the
purpose of consulting with and securing the cooperation of the Post Commander in
the installation of a plaque and to inspect the building and decide definitely just
where the marker should be located. The Commanding Officer, Colonel E. C. Norman,
assured us that it would give him great pleasure to cooperate and it was agreed that
he would arrange for the preparation of a concrete base to which the plaque would
be attached. Gen. Reed and Col. Siler then inspected the building which was erected
more than 50 years ago, has screened porches on the first and second floor front, has
shrubbery along the front and was converted into apartments for military personnel
many years ago. We agreed that the only practical location for a sign or plaque would
be on the sloping lawn between the building and the sidewalk.

Col. Siler stated that he consulted with Gen. Kean and was instructed to as-
certain the estimated cost of a bronze plaque if secured from commercial sources and
also whether a wooden marker could be prepared at the Army Medical Center without
cost to the Association. It was agreed tentatively that the wording on the plaque
would be as follows:
WALTER REED
died in this building,
then a hospital,
Nov 23 - 1902.

The Washington firm, Lamb Seal & Stencil Company, was requested to submit an
estimate of the cost of a suitable bronze plaque, corinthian style border, 20" x
12" in size, with necessary attachments for installation. Their estimate was approxi-
mately $79.00. A sketch of the proposed plaque, actual size, was inspected by the
members of the Board.

Col. Siler stated that he also had consulted with the Executive Officer, Army
Medical Center, relative to the preparation of a suitable wooden marker and had been
advised that they would be pleased to prepare such a marker, approximately 20" x 12"
in size, without cost to the Association. They suggested a black, rough, wooden
background with gold-colored letters, suitably finished for constant exposure to the
elements. They loaned him a completed sign showing the material and finish that
would be used in the preparation of the proposed marker and this sign was inspected
by the members of the Board.

After some discussion, the Treasurer was authorized to purchase a bronze plaque
to cost about $80.00 with the understanding that before placing the order considera-
tion would be given to the possibility of making such changes in the wording as might
more definitely assure permanent designation of the site if and when the now existing
building is replaced.

Col. Siler stated that the third matter referred to in Dr. Hench's letter was
that the year 1950 will be the 50th anniversary of Walter Reed's work on yellow fever
and it was his feeling that some notice of this event by the press would be appropri-
ate. The members of the Board were in complete agreement with Dr. Hench concerning
this matter and also agreed that the details of securing adequate press coverage
should be left to him with the understanding that he would call on Gen. Kean and the
Secretary of the Board for any pertinent data that he might consider necessary. This
matter will be taken up with Dr. Hench when he visits Washington in the near future.

The fourth matter referred to by Dr. Hench in his letter related to the delay
on the part of the Cuban Government in the matter of protecting Walter Reed's
Building No. 1 used in the conduct of experimental transmission of yellow fever.
Several years ago Dr. Hench and Mr. Moran located this building. Dr. Hench felt that
the building and immediate area should be converted into a permanent memorial. The
initial step in such a plan would be to protect, temporarily, Building No. 1 by
covering it with galvanized iron. In 1948 Dr. Hench offered to do this at his own
expense. Officials of the Cuban Government aovised him that they proposed to estab-
lish a permanent memorial and would provide a galvanized iron covering for the
building. Subsequently, the Cuban Government passed a bill to establish a permanent
memorial and set aside $50,000. for the project. Shortly thereafter a newly elected
government came into power and so far no steps have been taken to protect Building
No. 1. Dr. Hench made inquiry as to whether it might be possible through Mr. Johnson,
the Secretary of Defense, and diplomatic channels to prevail on the Cuban authorities
to take steps, at least, to provide temporary protection for Building No. 1. Col.
Siler discussed this matter with Gen. Bliss, Surgeon General of the Army, and he told
Col. Siler that he would be very glad to give any help within his power.

The Board then agreed that this matter would be held in abeyance pending Dr.
Hench's visit to Washington at which time action could be taken after he had con-
ferred with Gen. Bliss and Gen. Kean.

There being no further business the meeting adjourned to meet at the call of
the President.
